conclusion: The two vertical plates are initially uncharged, so the electric field between them is zero.
The only force on the small ball is its weight G = m g (directed vertically downward).
Consequently the ball falls straight down along AB.
A potential difference U is applied to the parallel plates separated by distance d.
A uniform electric field appears between the plates whose magnitude is E = U / d.
The charged ball (charge q) now experiences an electric force F_e = q E = q U / d.
This electric force is horizontal, perpendicular to the gravitational force.
According to the figure, once the field is switched on the ball begins to move along BC, which makes an angle of 45° with the original vertical line AB.
Therefore the resultant force R acting on the ball is directed exactly 45° away from the vertical.
Draw the vector triangle of forces: vertical component: G, horizontal component: F_e, resultant: R (along BC, 45° from vertical).
For the resultant to be 45° from the vertical we must have tan 45° = F_e / G = 1 ⇒ F_e = G.
Solve for the charge q: F_e = q U / d = G ⇒ q = G d / U.
If one writes the weight explicitly as G = m g, q = m g d / U.
The sign of q would depend on which plate is at the higher potential; the problem only asks for the amount of charge, so the magnitude |q| is given above.
The required charge on the small ball is q = G d / U (or q = m g d / U in terms of mass).
